How does the integration of PLM predicti: By incorporating a PLM-derived position-specific probability matrix into the Rosetta energy function, favoring evolutionarily plausible sequences.
By increasing the computational efficiency of the Rosetta software suite.
By automatically generating 3D models of proteins without user input.
By enhancing the visualization capabilities of protein structures.
What challenge did the study identify wi: Sequences designed by Rosetta often scored worse in terms of PLM metrics compared to their native counterparts.
Rosetta-designed sequences frequently failed to bind to target proteins.
The sequences were unstable at physiological temperatures.
Rosetta's designs were unable to fold into the desired tertiary structures.
What is the primary focus of integrating: Improving the design of protein sequences, including potential SARS-CoV-2 nanobody binders, by leveraging evolutionary information.
Enhancing the speed of computational simulations for protein folding.
Increasing the thermal stability of designed proteins under extreme conditions.
Developing new algorithms for predicting protein-ligand interactions.
What validation methods were used to ass: Independent methods like ProteinMPNN and OmegaFold were used to validate the designed sequences.
Experimental assays measuring binding affinity were conducted.
In vivo testing in animal models was performed.
X-ray crystallography was used to determine the structures of the designed proteins.
What was a key result of integrating PLM: The sequences had better PLM scores, indicating closer alignment with natural evolutionary patterns while maintaining similar thermodynamic stability.
The sequences showed increased resistance to proteolytic degradation.
The sequences demonstrated improved binding affinity to a wide range of targets.
The sequences exhibited enhanced solubility in aqueous solutions.
